node.title: The flower giver: Spreading joy, one bunch at a time
node.description: A Tairua woman picked and delivered more than 300 bunches of flowers for people in her town in just two weeks with the sole purpose of spreading joy.

node.title: Flood-hit Canadian province limits petrol purchases, non-essential travel
node.description: British Columbia imposes restrictions on fuel and non-essential travel to ease supply chain disruptions and support recovery work after floods and mudslides that have destroyed roads, houses and left thousands stranded.

node.title: Cricket Australia admits it should have disclosed Paine investigation
node.description: Cricket Australia's current leadership team says the organisation made a mistake by not revealing in 2018 it was investigating Time Paine's role in a text-messaging incident with a woman, which has led to his resignation as men's Test captain.

node.title: Today's sports news: What you need to know
node.description: In today's sports news - Paul Coll wins in London, another bonus-point victory for the Otago Sparks and players need to be vaccinated for Australian Open.

node.title: Harmful ingredients lurking in vape products - study
node.description: The largest New Zealand study into vape products showed harmful bacteria, substances and chemicals are lurking in them.

node.title: Jury acquits US teen shooter Kyle Rittenhouse of all charges
node.description: A jury has acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse on charges that he murdered two men and attempted to kill a third during chaotic 2020 racial justice protests in Wisconsin.

node.title: Florida Veterans Group Gives Dog to 700th Service Member and First Vietnam Vet
node.description: "Coming to K9s For Warriors and receiving Loose has been the best experience of my life," the veteran said.

node.title: Twelve people to stand trial over Kardashian West jewel heist in Paris
node.description: The charges relate to a 2016 robbery when the reality TV star was tied up at gunpoint and locked in a bathroom in her rented Paris apartment.

node.title: Other legal fallout from the violence in Kenosha is still playing out in the courts.
node.description: Civil lawsuits accuse the authorities of wrongdoing, both during the turbulence in the city and in the police shooting that sparked it.

node.title: Kitten Up An Electricity Pole Rescued and Reunited With Worried Owner
node.description: The 9-month-old kitten disappeared from her owner's home on November 13. Her owner later found her on a pole near her home.

node.title: 'Mud on their hands': Cricket Australia criticised for handling of Paine sexting scandal
node.description: Former players question the governing body's management of the incident, which has led to Tim Paine stepping down as the Australian men's Test captain ahead of the Ashes series.

node.title: England cricket apologises for racism
node.description: England's major cricketing bodies collectively apologised to all those who have suffered racism and discrimination in the game.

node.title: Film Festival director departs after two seasons
node.description: The director of Whānau Mārama: New Zealand International Film Festival has resigned, after just two seasons in the role.

node.title: Smaller crowds for anti-lockdown protests
node.description: Fewer people than at previous events have attended anti-lockdown protests around the country this afternoon.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 172 community cases in New Zealand today
node.description: There are 172 community cases of Covid-19 in the country today, with 148 identified in Auckland, the Ministry of Health says.

node.title: Five deaths, more than 1100 cases as Victoria sees restrictions ease
node.description: There are 1166 new Covid-19 cases and five people have died as Victoria enters its its first weekend with new relaxed restrictions.

node.title: Cracks in building: 'If someone's under it they're going to be dead'
node.description: Safety precautions have been taken outside a Dunedin building after a concerned citizen informed the city council about precarious-looking cracks.

node.title: PM's performance at COP26 behind Allegra Spender's tilt at seat of Wentworth
node.description: The realisation that Scott Morrison was "never going to get there" at the climate conference in Glasgow was the tipping point for Carla Zampatti's daughter to run in next year's federal election.

node.title: 'That route is closed': Unvaccinated travellers banned from entering Northern Territory
node.description: The Northern Territory will become the second jurisdiction in Australia to ban unvaccinated arrivals, with only limited exceptions, under sweeping changes to border rules announced by the Chief Minister.

node.title: Joe Biden, Unlike Trump, Didn't Take Cognitive Test in Annual Exam, Sanjay Gupta Says
node.description: Gupta agreed that the president was fit to successfully execute the duties of the presidency.

node.title: Two wounded as protests against COVID-19 measures turn violent in the Netherlands
node.description: Crowds of rioters in the Dutch port city of Rotterdam torch cars and throw rocks at police after several hundred people gathered to voice opposition to government plans to restrict access to indoor venues.

node.title: Photos from the sky show lush green paddocks turning into brown inland seas
node.description: Aerial and satellite imagery reveals the extent of inland NSW flooding, but it may only be a preview of what is on the way.

node.title: China disavows knowledge of tennis star's disappearance following rape allegation
node.description: Chinese authorities maintain they are unaware of the controversy surrounding missing tennis player Peng Shuai, as men's player Novak Djokovic says he supports the idea of cancelling tournaments in China until the issue is resolved.

node.title: 'Pillars of our democracy': Labor pledges to restore funding to ABC and SBS
node.description: Arguing the electoral cycle is leaving public broadcasters vulnerable, Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese says a Labor government would provide funding certainty for the ABC and SBS.

node.title: Rittenhouse and the Right’s White Vigilante Heroes
node.description: The great threat is that there are young men out there who watched the verdict and now want to follow Rittenhouse’s lead.

node.title: Oklahoma Lawmaker Who Supports Death Penalty Laments Its Possible End in His State
node.description: Oklahoma has had a series of bungled legal injections, such as John Marion Grant's execution on Oct. 28. He was given Midazolam which caused him to convulse.

node.title: Senate Unanimously Confirms First Native American Leader of National Park Service
node.description: Charles Sams III was confirmed by unanimous vote in the Senate Thursday, the first confirmed director of the National Park Service since 2017.

node.title: 'Buy Firearms and Form Christian Militias': Far Right Reacts to Rittenhouse Verdict
node.description: One extremism expert has warned that the Rittenhouse verdict will give a "blank check" for extremists to commit political violence.

node.title: Investigation Into Former Gov. Cuomo Shows He Misrepresented Nursing Home COVID Deaths
node.description: Former Gov. Andrew Cuomo's administration decided to exclude the deaths of patients transferred to hospitals from its overall death tolls for nursing homes.

node.title: Two wounded as Dutch police fire shots at protest over new Covid restrictions
node.description: Crowds of rioters in Rotterdam torched cars and threw rocks at police who responded with shots and water cannons, as protests against Covid-19 measures turned violent.
